13814738.review:
Awesome game. Epic

At first I was expecting something like Unity of Command.
But this game is so much deeper, yet accessible and easy to get into.
Simply a blast to play.

But the game is also very difficult, you have to do everything near-perfectly, especially if you want to get
a decisive victory.

But why? Because depending how you play the game, whether you get a normal victory, or get your objectives done quickly to get a decisive victory, will change which missions you are given by high command.

For example the invasion of Poland; invade Poland efficiently and quickly, and show that you are worthy, and you will be assigned to take on the daunting task of the invasion of Norway.
But achieve a regular victory, and you'll be assigned to take Belgium instead.

Also you have core units which you maintain throughout the game, which can gain medals, have heroes within them recognized (giving a stat boost) and gain valuable experience.
(Hint: Alt-Click on a unit to see it's war history and status)

There's just so much to enjoy here, this is a big game and if you get into it like I have been, will chew through your time.
It took me 6 hours, just to complete the Tutorial.
And as of writing this I've logged 20 hours, and am only on Mission 3.
Though mostly that's because I've had to restart each mission so many times to keep from out-right failing.
It's good to be challenged in the brain area by a game some times.

Also the game may look simple graphically, but non-the-less it draws you in.
The sprites are all HD and well-detailed, the sound effects make you feel like you're in the action,
and even the muzzle flashes and smoke drawn during attacks give the game that much more of a 'feel'.

The downside to the game, if you'd call it that, is the DLC.
Don't get me wrong, the DLC, from what I've heard, is awesome, and adds a heavy dose of content to the game.
But the price-tag is a little steep.
That being said I have only heard good things about the DLC and am planning on buying the lot of it soon.

If you're looking for a realistic, tactical-war turn-based strategy game, I cannot think of a better one out there.
Get it 10/10, epic.

13610085.review:
Cons: 
- EXPENSIVE ($80 for a collection !!!)
- Repetetive (click, point, click, point, click, point, etc).
- While overall the graphics are fine, some aspects remain problematic.  Trees are extremely tiny, look like bushes on the map, forests or trees adjasent to forests extend over tiles which are classified as fields making strategic planning often burdensome
- Simplistic.  Units health = 10, what does this mean?, why not show actual numbers of soldiers, equipment?  Supply map is not well explained/shown/integrated/conceptualized by the player, while supply is very important in grand strategy games in Panzer Corp you can be encircled over a wide area and still be fully supplied, how is that possible? Simply run on the map to the marked points (usually cities), knocking out enemy units on the way without worrying much about supplies, partisants or any other side-aspects of a typical 20th century warfare.  Very limited focus on units morale (all units generally have high morale, I guess German morale in Russia in the 1940s was generally good <-- NO IT WASNT, look at historic photographs and battle statistics)
- No understanding what the units actually represent leads me to form a very poor bond with my 
  units.  Are these units divisions, armies?  What are these formations? (for exmaple, AT gun unit, does this mean its several platoons with AT guns?, but then how can this be when the map streches over 100s of kilometers and there are only about 60 units on the map).  When a unit reaches 0/10 its destroyed (kind of an arcade time count)
- No battle/war statistics displayed at the end of each campaign/war (this is a historic grand strategy game so tables, graphs, performance charts is a MUST HAVE! )

Pros: 
- Decent selection of equipment from the era.  
- Decent graphics with well visible/recognizable unit icons
- Awards to particular units for bravery or other special achievements
- Simple click, point and click strategy game on a hex-based board layout (this might be a drawback for some, see below)

________________________________________________________________

More about the problems:
The collection is EXTREMELY EXPENSIVE, the game is basically the old Panzer General series, its a simple hex-based board game, with slightly better (its a 2D graphics so you shouldnt expect much in the graphics department), maybe a few new units and mostly just new maps.  I mean COMMON $80 for dozens of new 2D maps for $80, REALLY?  Skyrim with its excellent 3D graphics and a much more complex engine was not even as expensive as Panzer Corps Collection is now.  Yes the developers state that this is a BRILLIANT REMAKE or some crap like that on their website, however they dont justify that argument with neither specific explanations about why its presumably so much better than the old, nor have I experiance anything new playing this game.  Considering that you can get Panzer General 2 for several dollars online and there hundreds (if not thousands) of FREE maps/campaigns made over the last 20 years or so which can be downloaded online, the games price is simply out of norm at the moment.  Also, some aspects of the older games were actually better than in this most recent one.  For example, I actually preferred the terrain in Panzer General 2 over this game (e.g., vegetation type, such as tree cover, was far more pleasent and recognizable in the old one).  Automatic switching between ground units and air units (e.g., when you move an air unit to attack a ground unit) is very clumsy and in some cases does and sometmes it does not result in an attack (you have to execute the command once more after you place the air unit of ground unit to attack).  There are other problems with the game, but these do not neccessarly reflect a sole problem of Panzer Corps but rather a general design flaw with hex-based war games (e.g., AT guns = if these are inf units equiped with AT guns, why are they weaker than regular inf units which lack AT guns?).

Publishers Censorship:
Aside from the game itself, the developer has been known to block/censor people on steam forum who complain about aspects of the game, such as the extremely high cost of the game.  Basically someone posts a message stating that the game price is overblown, then some other users (potentialy someone who works for the developer as this has been repeated numerous times on steam forum) posts a comment criticising the original comment with some unpleasent remarks (not even swear words), then the original poster responds to it with more unpleasent remarks (again, no swear words) and then the publisher quickly blocks the post and bans the original person posting the comment criticising the high cost of the game PERMANENTLY stating that the person has made an unpleasent comment !  Simple corporate scheme to block critique against the buisness strategy of the company.

13504408.review:
* Estrategia por turnos
* Gran número de unidades
* Experiencia, Héroes, Medallas
* Suministros de munición y combustible
* Moral (Miedo y Fatiga)
* Meteorología
* 1939 - 1945 Grandes Batallas de la Segunda Guerra Mundial
* 40 Grandes Batallas de la Historia
* DLCs: Más de 200 niveles y la oportunidad de jugar como los Aliados, el Afrika Korps o recorrer los escenarios de la guerra de manera histórica para que no te pierdas nada.


De los creadores de Panzer General Forever llega este fantástico remake de Panzer General.

Ponte al frente de la Wehrmacht para participar en las batallas más significativas de la 2ª Guerra Mundial.
Mediante un sistema de juego por turnos podrás dirigir unidades de tierra (infantería, tanques, vehículos de reconocimiento, piezas de artillería y cañones antitanque...), aire y mar. *

( * Solo podrás progresar y administrar unidades de tierra y aire. Las unidades navales serán específicas del mapa y contarán como refuerzos. )


Cada unidad podría considerarse un batallón o regimiento desde un punto de vista táctico en relación al tamaño de los mapas y al tipo y cantidad de unidades a manejar.

El juego dispone de una variedad inmensa de unidades. Ya sean distintos roles de infantería (regular, pesada, ingenieros, montañeros, etc.) o unidades de diferentes tipos y versiones ( panzer iii e, f, g etc. / bf 109 / bf 110 ) podrás ir adquiriendo unidades durante el transcurso del juego para que puedas disponer de las unidades apropiadas para el trabajo requerido.

Siembra el pánico entre tus enemigos con la artillería para debilitar sus defensas antes de lanzar a tus soldados al ataque.
Envía a tus bombarderos en contra de sus columnas de tanques y destruye sus líneas de abastecimiento.
Gracias a los bombardeos estratégicos podrás tener el efecto de la artillería haya donde quieras de manera rápida y efectiva.


Cada unidad llevará un registro de sus acciones para ir ganando experiencia y recibir condecoraciones (meramente estéticas), así como promocionar el ascenso de 'héroes' que proporcionen bonus a su unidad.


Las unidades tienen limítes de munición y combustible que les obliga a detenerse 1 turno a repostar.
En el caso de las unidades aéreas deberán volver al aeródromo más cercano.
Las unidades navales disponen de suministros muy amplios pero en caso de necesidad, habrá puertos marítimos.

Por eso es muy importante la posesión de ciudades y puntos de suministros.
A modo de puntos de captura, esta será la parte más importante del juego. La conquista de Europa.


Cada escenario dispondrá de un nº limitado de turnos (~20) para conseguir dichos objetivos.


Durante cada turno, existe un sistema de metereología que hará que ciertos turnos tengamos el tiempo en nuestra contra.
Tormentas, cielos nublados, nevadas...ralentizarán a nuestro ejército y llegarán a impedir incluso el uso de apoyo aéreo.


Dependiendo del éxito o el fracaso de tus operaciones, irás recorriendo los escenarios-batallas de la segunda guerra mundial, pudiendo llegar a combatir en escenarios supuestos. ¿Qué habría pasado con América y el Reino Unido si Alemania hubiese sometido a la Unión Soviética y hubiese podido estar preparada para repeler el desembarco en Normandía? Descúbrelo!

13498510.review: As stated by other reviewers, this is a revised and updated Panzer General. Great fun (assuming you liked PG or turn based strategy in general), incredible diversity of scenarios if you buy the DLC. Gameplay and graphics are solid, never had an issue of any kind. If there is anything negative it is that the more difficult settings are well balanced in the early years of the Grand campaign (playing as Germany), but once you reach 1943 it becomes nearly impossible to maintain a core force and therefore you will also end up fielding units of old men and middle school kids. Playing as the Allies you will roll through later years of campaign. Of course this is what happened IRL and you might argue that the game reflects the historical imbalance of production/manpower and ultimately hopeless situation of the Nazi's. Either way it is fun, there is some replayability in terms of applying different mix of units to the same scenarios, and I keep coming back to it from time to time to try different strategies and increase the difficulty.  If you buy, get the Grand Campaign DLC and if it is ever in a Steam Sale this is a no brainer for any turn based strategy fans, particularly those who have fond memories of Panzer General or enjoy WWII as a setting.

13372123.review:
I finally picked up Panzer Corps a few weeks ago, after waiting for it to go on sale--it's not cheap.  Like many other reviewers, I was a big fan of Panzer General and the Steel Thunder games back in the stone age. On the surface, Panzer Corps seems like a pretty straightforward reboot of those titles. It has a lot more depth, though. The game seems insanely easy to play at first--the interface is as straightforward and clear as anything. There are definitely right and wrong ways to do things, though.  It's rewarding to find out that Panzer Corps responds in the ways you expect it to, though--if you have a reasonable grasp of what the different unit types are supposed to do, it's fun to discover that your dreams of being an armchair Rommel actually work out.

There's a huge variety of unit types, and it's really fun to build up the core of your army throughout a campaign. You really start to care about your units. In one campaign I was invading Sicily and feeling way too confident...I let my prized British commando unit (elites that couldn't be replaced) get chewed up by the Germans when I got cocky. It was one of those slo-mo 'no no no nonooooooooooooooo' moments, hehe.

Oh, and after a bad day at work and/or with the gf/wife/whatever you've got, PC has the perfect solution to your problems.  Start a Wehrmacht '39 campaign on the easiest setting, and just roflstomp your way through the baby seals.

Great game.  Totally addictive.  Get it.

팬저 제너럴 팬이라면 제값을 주고 사도 후회는 없다. 망설인다면 할인할 때 사자!


구매를 고려하는 분들을 위해, 본편과 DLC의 내용을 정리해보자면,


본편 - 독일의 1939~1945 까지의 여정으로, 약 20여개의 시나리오가 있다.

그랜드 캠페인 DLC - 본편처럼 독일의 1939부터 1945까지를 다루는데, 년도별로 15여개의 시나리오씩 세분화 되어있다.

얼라이드 포스 DLC - 영,미,호주 연합군의 전투를 1940~1945 까지 다룬 DLC이다.

플레이어가 어렵게 키운 유닛들이, 하나 둘 씩 해체되어 가며, 역사대로 독일의 고충을 느낄 수 있다.

13236175.review:
Panzer Corps can be qualified as a successor to the famous and rewarded Panzer General series. 

In this game you take command of the German forces in World War II, sometimes assisted by their allies and must complete various objectives such as destroying a target or more often conquer the map. Panzer Corps is a turned-based 2D game which means that you organise your movements, attacks or other strategic action before the enemy does his. 

The German campaign will lead you in several theaters of the war such as the invasion of France, the taking of Norwegian's Narvik city, the assistance of Italian troops in their invasion of Greece or the famous operation Barbarossa. The campaign offers a continuity in the various operations which means you will keep your units from a theater to another. That way you will quickly care for your troops as they gain experience, medals and war heroes and you will try to keep the best of your regiments alive. Loosing a battle does not mean the end of the campaign or that you will automatically have to start again but you will continue the fight with a scenario according to your defeat. 

[b][u]Now let's see the highs and lows of the game :[/b][/u]

- Good replayability : with various difficulties and numerous strategies possible you will like to start again a scenario and try to win it a different way.
- The difficulty levels : They really offer a different difficulty which will accomodate the different kinds of players from novice to the master generals/ 
- The map is not just there to be pretty: Like a proper wargame, terrains matter. You may not want to attack while crossing a river, forests take longer to cross and units will move differently depending on their transport system ( trucks, on foot,...Etc )
- Graphisms : Some will say come on we are in the 2010s but I like the graphism. The interface is very good and clean which is not always the case in these games and the units are clean as well. Once you are accustomed you will recognize the unit by their looks easily. 
- The sounds : there are not many sounds but they are correct and not horrible. Repetitive but very correct. The same goes with the music, it's not an epic music but it's enjoyable You may quickly forget that there is music though.
- Multiplayer
-Tutorial ( some games forget about tutorials so it's a good point. I jumped right into the game but for novice players it is important ).
- There are achievements will add some new objectives if you like that kind of things.
- Very fast, the end turns are quick ( The End of All Wars ? )
- There is a demo on the official website. Some people don't care but I find very important that games have a demo, only to see if it works on your computer. 

- Where are the objectives ? Only when you end you turn and that's a shame. It's either hidden very well and in that case it's a low point as well but I can't find a single button to see my objectives during my turn. 

What follows is neither a high nor a low point: The DLCs. They had several new campaign ( the base game with the German campaign and the multiplayer already offers a lotn enough to see if you like the game ) such as with the Afrika Corps, the allied or more focused scenarios such as the year 1940,...Etc I bought two of them and I am happy with them. DLCs don't take away anything from the base game they just had new campaigns for those who want more. Some may not like it but at least features were not taken from the base game to be sold after as DLCs like so many games do. 

So I highly recommand this, for old Panzer General and the like fans as well for novice in this genre. It's very intuitive and you will soon get into the game without headaches. During my first play, I find myself playing three hours in a row withou t noticing time passing. 8.5/10

13144700.review: An introductory level wargame that skimps on realism to deliver "beer and pretzels", jump right in and conquer the world goods.  You'll be playing the campaign as any individual scenario is not particularly compelling and definitely is NOT a historical simulation of its respective battle.  The campaign is a blast to play, though as you'll be given a core force of Wehrmacht units representing Infantry, Artillery, Panzer, etc of possibly brigade/division size.  IMO, the units have no realistic size as the game is abstracted and for funsies.  As you conquer cities and finish battles, you'll accumulate "influence" points with which you can upgrade your existing units and buy new ones.  In addition, your units accumulate experience when they fight which will make them more effective and randomly generate leaders attached to the unit that gives them special abilities like +1 Movement, for example.  As the war progresses, new units will unlock as your original units become obsolete.  You'll start the war with PzKfw I and end with Tiger IIs.  The campaign has branching possibilities depending on the victory level you achieve, so it is possible to invade England, e.g.  My beefs with the game are few.  The main one being that the base game is short (but replayable) and to properly enjoy the game, one should purchase the Grand Campaign.  The game overall has an admirable level of polish.  Wish there was more animation. Don't expect depth or realism.  This is War lite, playable while drunk.

13143337.review:
A modern recreation of Panzer General, a game from ye olde, Panzer Corps plays with the same classic gameplay of the original, kicked into the 21st Century.

Giving the option of a progressive campaign, or both single and multiplayer independent scenarios, the Second World War comes back to life with the renouwned almost chess-like system of balance between Infantry, Armour, Reconnaisance, Anti-Armour, Artillery, AA, Fighters, and Tactical & Strategic Bombers. Each unit has its' own advantages, strengths and weaknesses - a King Tiger is truely a powerful tank, but it cannot win the war alone! With the original prestige system the game forces you to adapt your strategy around the battlefield: if you're taking heavy losses, should I pull-back, give them green reinforcements, or veterans? As you push through the campaign, with a choice of five starting years, your core forces follow through, gaining experience, and eventually medals and heroes.

The flexibility of tactics allow your preferences to come out in your core and mission results. Choices such as those between ground attack and fighter-bomber aircraft: early in the game, you have the Ju87 Stuka and the Bf110. The Stuka is a more reliable source of damage, but more vulnerable to enemy interceptors and anti-air fire whilst the 110 can engage other aircraft, typically used to finish off shattered aircraft or mop up craft that cannot do much back like bombers, as well as faring better in air combat, but at the cost of less performance in ground strikes.
Anti-tank, artillery, or anti-aircraft weapons on a tank chassis make for faster, more reliable defence and offense, but at a higher price and losing out on the bonuses crewed non vehicle weapons obtain - as they are not armoured, they fare better in close terrain and hold better ambush advantages, amongst other things. Sometimes a mix is better - keeping general support weapons with main attacks whilst giving mechanised AA, AT and artillery to tank groups to better support their attacks can benefit both. But now you're dividing your forces into two distinct groups and you have to weigh up whether the advantages are enough!

A range of scenarios are present in the game: relive the humble beginnings in Poland, to the start of the turning point in the Caucauses - from all the major operations in the war, but also covering hypothetical situations - what would be the real outcome of a German invasion of the British Isles, or even an invasion of the American east coast?

A strong variety of units are present. Progressive models of vehicles like tanks and fighters give you the oppertunity to upgrade as history produced each - even the late-war Panzer IV J has it's roots in the D model! Is the cost always worth it for the battle? Much of your choices may reflect necessities found in the real war, such as the shock of heavier armour in Barbarossa! Different types of each group present theirselves - infantry are diverse: light, heavy, mountain, paratroop, engineer, bridge-laying, cavalry, motorised and so on, and this type of diversity is continued in the unit groups. Upgrade your units! Infantry, anti-tank, artillery and the like can be given transport. The first option is the classic Opel Blitz truck, which gets you where you need. However, as a mere truck, it is highly susceptible to attack and as such many choose to upgrade some of their units to use the sd.kfz 251 or 250 halftracks which also benefit from the ability to fire when under attacked (or when the risky commander chooses to engage enemies!) Throughout the campaign, you also have the chance to obtain prototype and unique units, from the tremendous Schwere-Gustav railgun to the infamous Maus.

Finally, if you wish to continue, the devs have bundled up new content in the form of two expansion packs, Allied & Afrika Corps, for a new experience, and the Grand Campaign which allows you to progress through all notable battles in the war: 1939 is now split into fourteen seperate scenarios! Carve your route through the war - your successes or failures will decide factors such as whether your force attacks through the Danzig North or Danzig South corridor in Poland, or whether to obey orders or mount an assault on the Dunkirk evacuation! Many of the scenarios have been bundled with unique objectives. For instance, one scenario in 1940 challenges you to assault positions to extract a French general and take him to the rear of the map, whilst one Polish situation requires you to halt troop trains to gain a decisive victory! Now get out there herr oberleutnant, and turn the course of the war!

13119235.review:
So what is Panzer Corps ? 

Panzer Corps is an exact copy of Panzer General II updated for mordern computers.  That's it.  Overall this a pretty great classic game.  I can't count the number of hours that I spent playing the original, and there is absoultely nothing wrong with this game.  Would buy again.

The only comment I will make is that if you are looking to see what a modern hex based WWII game looks like, then you should also pick up a copy of "Unity of Command", which was clearly influenced by Panzer General II, but which has its own really fresh take on hex based wargames.

13117360.review:
The tried and true formula so familiar to the classic Panzer General fans gets a second wind in Panzer Corps. You get to command a mostly persistent force through a number of historical and hypothetical WWII campaign scenarios that unravel depending on progress and success in prior battles. It's thanks to tactical depth, freedom and replayability as well as an unprecedented scale of campaigns found in both the base game and especially the numerous DLCs that Panzer Corps deserves in my mind the title of the best turn-and-hex based strategy game of 2014.

Accessible for even those players completely unfamiliar with the genre conventions, it's a gem worth checking out even at the current steep price. As far as DLCs are concerned, the Grand Campaign '39-'45 is a must for fans of the genre.

13093693.review: Is ridiculously deep strategy game with an easy to learn surface, but a million fathoms of strategic depth to uncover.  The game's main feature is the dynamic campaign, each scenario has specific parametres to achieve "decisive victory" these are like "S" ranking a mission in other games and it is actually quite hard to achieve a decisive victory even in the early levels.  I often found myself getting a decisive victory on the last turn.  If you win through any other means it is a mere "marginal victory" and this is where the game gets really interesting.  A marginal victory is cause history to play out normally, but a decisive victory will lead into scenarios like Operation Sea Lion.  Furthermore, your core units (as long as they survive) will persist between scenarios in the campaign, they can also gain medals and have heroes added to them depending on their performance.  If you are a strategy fan this may scratch that itch for you.

12943030.review:
I love this game. Simply put, it is an equal or better to the old Panzer General games. So many indie games have tried to copy Panzer General, a seemingly simple task, and failed. Unit experience, branching campaigns, over strength units, huge numbers of individual vehicles and infantry types, and a simple and clean interface. This one ships with small campaigns and a full grand campaign that branches in alt-history directions, but once you play that you will want to start picking up the add-on packs, which imho are worth the price of admission. Just buy them as you play them or wait for a big sale. My advice, after you've played through the main game, pick up the Afrika Korps campaign. It's long, with more alt history twists and turns if you succeed at your objectives. 

I have spent a lot of good money on lame pretenders to the PG throne on Steam over the years. Here, finally, is a worthy successor.

Panzer Corps é um jogo de estratégia em turnos que dá continuidade a famosa franquia Panzer General I/II. O título recria importantes batalhas da Segunda Guerra Mundial colocando o jogador no controle das forças da Wehrmacht — forças armadas do Terceiro Reich — e seus temíveis Panzerkampfwagen.

A campanha engloba 26 cenários, sendo que o andamento das trama pode variar de acordo com o seu desempenho em cada embate. A jogabilidade é simples e direta, o que torna Panzer Corps extremamente acessível mesmo para o mais inexperiente dos jogadores.

Panzer Corps é um verdadeiro jogo de estratégia clássico (não esse jogos de ação que dizem ter estratégia). Destaque nesse jogo fica para a evolução em campanha de seus generais e os DLC's Afrika Corps e Allied General. Vale a pena a jogatina.

12237721.review:
If you've played Panzer General before and you liked it, then that's all you need to know. This is basically a direct copy-update of the game.

What you REALLY want though, is the Grand Campaign. That alone is worth the full price twice over, it's literally what it says on the tin. A grand campaign from 39-45 and it is much better paced than the stand alone game. It's also very good at representing what went on in the war and provides a nice learning curve. You'll stomp through Poland with ease, bounce up through Norway, smash the French as if they weren't there (after some minor resistance from the Belgians) and you'll feel epic as a General after having all those conquests. More so when you raid the Balkans.

Then you go off against Russia, and it's easy, you smash them, underequipped, out of supply, un prepared. And you're laughing, over your German beer and with your fraulein sitting in your lap, you're one of the best army generals in the Nazi Regime.

Then reality hits. The Russians mobilise, they get their airforce at you, their tanks roll towards you and the legions and legions of infantry just won't stop. Your puny Panzers' shells can't even stand up to their tanks, your anti-tanks get steamrolled, and its here, right on the battlefield in mother Russia that you'll find out whether your skills as a General are up to scratch. By the end of it, Poland and France will seem like a distant memory.

Reckon you're up to the challenge? Prove it! This game will push you to the limit.

11853204.review:
Overall: 9/10

Some 700 (seven hundred, holy.....!) hours later, and after over 220 scenarios I believe I am entitled to write a review of Panzer Corps, Panzer General's successor.

When I played the original Panzer General, back in '94, I remember the ashtrays quickly filling up as I kept on playing with a friend (swapping chairs when it was the other's turn). It was the first time I enjoyed a wargame on a computer, while my first grognard experience happened some ten years before when I was "inducted" through Avalon Hill's Third Reich boardgame. So, yes, I like my wargames.

Since this is a videoGAME review, I will try and wear the gamer's hat, rather than the hardcore grognard's helmet.

This review is based on a playthrough of the Grand Campaign, Afrika Corps and Allied Corps, so all the "DLCs", the full enchilada.

Pros:
- While the replayability is quite low, if it takes 650 hours to play through: even at full price, the cost opportunity is pretty good like 10 cents an hour.
- Each scenario is different and there's never a dull moment.
- The game is easy to learn and quite hard to master.
- The number of units (and the very different way to employ each and every one of them) as well as the historical research to build the scenarios is quite impressive.
- The game is virtually bug free. This should be a given, but it's worth mentioning considering the amount of junk that is unleashed on customers these days (Football Manager 2014, Rome Total War 2, and so forth).
- It runs smoothly on pretty much every rig / OS / graphic card.
- Far from being flashy, the graphics do their job.
- The addition of heros makes the experience more personal.
- The heavily scripted AI does its job at keeping you challenged.

Cons:
- Increasing difficulty beyond General level, rather than giving you more challenges, just increases the number of enemies  / or their equipment quality (to very ahistorical levels).
- The basic game feels like a demo compared to the Grand Campaign. definitely get all the DLCs.
- The hero traits are too random (ok, this is the grognard talking, but, seriously, Artillery units with "spotting" traits and Air units with "movement" benefits are really useless / non-sensical).

So, whether you are a gamer with a casual interest in World War 2 tactics or a tough wargamer who looks for something more relaxing, this game is damn near perfect.

11673256.review:
대전략(Grand Strategy), 워게이밍(Wargaming) 장르 불후의 명작, <팬저 제너럴>을 가장 완벽하게 부활시켰다는 찬사를 받은 게임이다. 역시 평단과 유저들의 호평을 얻어낸 비슷한 계통의 게임으론 여기 스팀에선 <유니티 오브 커맨드Unity Of Command>를 꼽을 수 있는데, 사실 UOC는 전략 게임이라기보단 퍼즐 게임에 가깝다. UOC와 달리 팬콥은 그야 말로 정통 전략 게임. 장르의 기본을 충실하게 지키면서 변화한 시대에 걸맞게 개선된 시스템과 UI로 접근성까지 대폭 높였다는 게 플레이어들의 중평이다. 

워게이밍 장르가 '어렵다'는 인식을 가지게 된 이유는 복잡한 인터페이스 때문인데, 팬콥은 여타 턴제 게임 수준의 단순간편한 인터페이스를 구현해냈다. 그렇다고 게임성까지 단순해졌을 거라 생각하면 오산. 물고 물리는 병과 간 상성 차이를 활용한 전략 운용이 아주 탄탄하게 구현되어 있고, 전략에 큰 영향을 미치는 다양한 속성의 타일들과, 운송/날씨/증원/보급 등 실제 전장의 상황을 영리하게 게임화한 시스템들이 전략에 깊이를 더해줘 연합군을 공략하는 재미가 쏠쏠하다. 전략 게임들을 애써 즐기지 않는 내가 이 만큼 재밌게 플레이 할 수 있을 정도면 캐쥬얼 게이머가 아닌 이상 아마 무조건 재밌게 할 수 있을 것이다.


결과적으로, 이 게임, 돈값은 한다. 유일한 흠이라면 80불에 달하는 콜렉션의 가격인데, 참고로 Afrika korps와 Allied Corps는 스탠드 얼론 확장판이며(DLC로 들어가 있어 별도 실행 가능한지는 미지수) 그랜드 캠페인 DLC들은 추가 시나리오 확장팩들이다. (그랜드 캠페인은 DLC 상품 페이지로 접속할 경우 10달러 저렴한 컴플팩으로 구매 가능) 

다행히 본편만으로도 플탐 20시간 정도의 온전한 컨텐츠를 즐길 수 있다. 그러니 턴제/전략/양차 대전 애호가들과 웰메이드 전략 게임을 찾는 고급 게이머들은 우선 본편부터 구입해보는 게 나을지도. 공홈에서 데모 버전을 다운받아 플레이해볼 수도 있는데, 어차피 데모 해보면 최소한 본편은 사게 되어 있으니 그냥 바로 본편을 사자.

11626561.review:
Obwohl ich ein großer Fan von Hexfeld-Strategie seit Battle Isle und vor allem History Line bin, ist Panzer Corps eine klare Enttäuschung!
Wer wie ich Panzer General 3D (PG3D) weit über 10 Jahre immer auf der Festplatte bereit hatte, wird Panzer Corps als zu armselig in der Fortentwicklung finden. Gerade für PG3D gab es sehr viele Mods, so dass Karten, Kampagnen und Einheiten zusammenkommen, die man hier nicht mal für den Komplettkauf aller teuren DLCs bekommt.
Bedauerlicherweise wurde am Spielprinzip des ersten Panzel General zu sehr festgehalten, ohne integrierte Zusatzmissionen/ reine Verteidigungsmissionen/ dynamischen Missions- und Kampagnenverlauf oä. 
Der Grafikstil ist natürlich Geschmackssache, aber eine runderneuerte Pseudo-3D-Grafik (Isometrie oä.) mit ein paar Animationen vglb. PG3D wäre technisch ebenso sehr sparsam gewesen, hätte aber einen deutlich schöneren Eindruch gemacht.
Der schlimmste Kritikpunkt und der endgültige Punkt, weshalb ich dieses Spiel nicht empfehlen kann, liegt im Fehlen eines dynamischen/skalierbaren Grafik-Userinfaces. Der einzige Monitor auf dem ich die Schrift und Icons noch erkennen kann, ist mein 28" mit 1440p, auf meinem Hauptmonitor mit 4k oder dem Notebook mit Retinaauflösung bräuchte man eine Lupe um irgendwas zu erkennen oder man muss sehr stark interpolieren lassen, was die Grafik aber so schlecht macht, dass ich gleich wieder PG3D spielen kann.

Pour les joueurs de l'ancienne école, la seule évocation de Panzer General est suffisante pour arracher un sourire de satisfaction nostalgique. On se souvient du mode campagne affriolant, des maps grandes et intéressantes, de l'interface simple, rendant parfaitement accessible au plus grand nombre ce wargame WWII, et puis ce charme, ce charme incroyable émanant des menus d'accueil, des petites vidéos d'archive en low-res avant le début d'une mission, etc.
Eh bien, comme son titre l'indique, Panzer Corps n'a pas d'autre but que de reprendre le flambeau, en mettant de côté la 3D pour retourner vers de la bonne vieille 2D à papa (nous vivons une époque bénie, il faut croire, les développeurs semblent avoir enfin compris que les joueurs attendent autre chose que de beaux jeux creux et sans âme d'une durée de vie de 3 heures).
Et le résultat est là : le connaisseur retrouvera presque instantanément ses marques et se lancera à corps perdu dans cette reconstitution étape par étape de la seconde guerre mondiale. Gorgé de contenu supplémentaire, le jeu avec tous ses add-ons prend une dimension tentaculaire, entendez par là plusieurs centaines d'heures de jeu. Qui s'en plaindra ?

The base game without DLC's is great.  Slitherine is very MOD friendly and plenty of user added content. 

The base game covers the major battles/operations the Campaign DLC's break these down into different phases.

9961528.review:
Ce jeu est le premier du genre que j'ai en ma possession. Je suis plus FPS, simulation aérienne etc je ne pensais jamais mettre les pieds sur Panzer corps, mais une fois une clé en ma possession je décide d'aller le tester. D'abord j'ai trouvé que c'était assez bizarre comme jeu et que je n'allais pas accrocher. Mais une fois le tutoriel fini et la campagne commencée je ne pouvais plus m'arrêter de jouer. Je retrouve un peu de Hearts of iron (dsl je n'ai que cette comparaison en tête) avec la météo, le fait de faire attention au terrain avant d'engager un combat (boueux, geler, montagneux etc...). Ce que j'adore c'est que nous avons la possibilité d'avoir un historique de nos armées, les médailles qu'elles ont reçues, depuis quand elles sont en service, les héros de guerre s'il y a (qui se sont distingués au combat), du coup on s'attache forcément à certaines divisions qui ont montré courage et savoir faire au combat. "Pendant l'attaque de Paris j'ai perdu un groupe de vétéran 3 étoiles avec tout un passé et ça m'a réellement fait chier."

Les combats sont bien foutu pour ce genre de jeu et leurs résultats sont parfois assez aléatoire si on ne fait pas attention à ce qu'il y a autour (météo, terrain, artillerie, aviation...). "Je pensais décimer la moitié de l'armée ennemi, mais c'était sans compter sur leurs artilleries qui étaient cachés dans un hexagone grisé et du coup je me suis retrouvé avec mon armée a moitié détruite, puis le tour s'est fini et se fût le même cas pour mon armée qui se prît une belle contre-attaque". Pour ce qui est des batailles navales je n'en ai fait que très peu, mais elles furent sympathique à jouer.

La bande son est génial, elle passe toute seule même si parfois elle peut être répétitive. Les sons des combats, explosions  sont bien fait, pas besoin d'avoir plus pour ce style de jeu je pense.

Je recommande vivement ce jeu il vaut le coup.

9758925.review:
First of all, it's not a bad game per se but it's simply not worth its price. You can get more for your money on steam. Save your money and buy CIV5, Unity of Command or TW instead if you are into turn-based strategy games.

As a fan of the classic Panzer General, I bought this game three years ago. It comes with just 26 scenarios, some of which are nearly identical. If you play a campaign, you won't come across all of them. I finished the campaign in less than 10 hours and I'm sure there are players who play faster than I. It's clear that Matrix wants you to buy its overpriced dlcs. In the end, you would end up spending 80 bucks on a game which is nothing more than a blatant clone of the classic Panzer General. It appears that because the original PG creator company SSI does not exist anymore they can do it without facing copyright infringement claims. 
If you are not used to the old Panzer General this game might be boring and dull to you. The graphics cannot compete with newer titles, the gameplay does not offer a lot of depth. All you have to do is drag your units from A to B. Even if you're fan of the original hit Panzer General, you should not touch it. There are several free ports and countless campaigns available for free.
9758925.developer_response:
Sorry you are not happy with the game but in our experience the vast vast majority of players who like Panzer General love Panzer Corps. I don't think it is possible to complete the game in less than 10 hours without cheating or playing in the easiest beginners mode so it could just be you lost track of time :) There are a huge number of multiplayer scenarios and vast amounts of user created content to add many more play hours to the game. The average time to complete the base game is about 30 hours though many more if you play multiplayer or the user content. 

We really don't feel the game or the DLC's are overpriced - each $5 DLC contains 2/3 of the content of the base game and the base game is only $19.99. 

If there is something you think we can do to improve the game for the future please post at the forums as we're continually improving and adding new stuff and are always keen to hear player feedback. 

The Slitherine Team

9676351.review:
Panzer Corps is a turn-based strategy or ‘wargame’. Each scenario you are tasked with deploying your troops and taking a set number of objectives across the map. Units earn experience and can be upgraded during the deployment phase with any new equipment unlocked. This is done using prestige points that you acquire by completing objectives and are also used to reinforce units during battle when they lose strength. Prestige points are persistent throughout the campaign meaning spending all of your points in one battle may not be wise as you are effectively depleting your resources for the next engagement; although you do receive some at the beginning of each scenario, what you have carries over.

The graphics of Panzer Corps are fairly basic although nice to look at with each type of unit distinguishable from each other. Sounds can also said to be somewhat basic as each unit type has a single sound that is played during movement and attack. This may sound repetitive however after 18 hours of playing Panzer Corps I can say this has yet to bother me. The interface is effective at doing the job and gives you access to all of the information you need without being intrusive.

Panzer Corps strikes a great balance between depth and accessibility and offers a great entry point into wargames for the uninitiated. The gameplay is addictive and the visuals and audio serve the game well, while the multiplayer uses a play-by-email method so multiple games can be played at once over the course of a few or more days.

Panzer Corps has quickly become one of my favourite games and I would happily recommend it to anyone.

9635736.review: Splendid!  If you liked Panzer General then this game is for you!

9626773.review:
I'll make a quick review of this game.
At first, most of you were probably thinking just like I was when I saw it the first time: How can you charge, That much, for something that looks quite like that which my (insert elderly familymember here) Would enjoy in his/her youth?

Well, if you do enjoy armchair general'ing and feel great joy when your tactic successfully dislodges that presistent little infantry unit from the city which all your stuff needs to go through.... Then this just might be for you!

Despite a somewhat elderly appearance, this game offers quite a bit of depth and does (especially true with its expansions and Grand Campaign) allow you some degree of choice. Also your units follow you from fight to fight (IF they survive). 
It also has a fairly alright difficulty editor for those of us who might not exactly be Eisenhower, Rommel or Montgomery, in terms of strategic prowess, so to a degree you can tailor your difficulty!

My recommendation, if you like strategy, and would enjoy taking it online, you should indeed give it a spin! It also offers a good campaign mode for single players.

I personally enjoy this game served in small doses on a rainy day, and sure enough, it has that good old "Just one more turn" issue with it, if you let yourself be immersed!

Wasting already over 30 hours, alone on the main campaign, i feel the need to write a recommendation for this really impressive strategy game.
If you´re in this kind of strategy and maybe played games like Panzer General and the many others in the "General" series (i for one also would still like a modern version of Fantasy General) from good old SSI, you already know, what to expect.

A deep and challenging campaign throughout the WW II time, with many varied unit types from each time of the war. The way you take is partly based on your success in the battles, if you manage to overtake the enemy fast enough, you can also change the course of history and get interesting hypothetical scenarios like invasion of GB or USA.
Beside the well thought out maps and unit strengths/weaknesses your motivation is also to keep your core units alive, which stay with you and get experience/heroes/medals with your victories. 
To lose your trusty reconnaissance unit after five years, truly hurts.

Surely it could use some comfort functions and the steam integration is still a bit lacking, but without question Panzer Corps is a must have for fans of this type of game.

9496622.review:
Easily my favorite war game on PC was the SSI classic Panzer General (1993).   PG went on to have 4-5 sequals and generally was a fan favorite for a decade.   Luckly for us Slitherine decided to dust off this classic with a bit newer graphics but the same old fun gameplay.   If you loved PG then stop reading this review buy the game and play.  If you are new to the series lets go over what makes it fun.  First unlike many other war games its very easy to pick up learn and enjoy.  Most gamers should be able to pick up most of what they need to learn in under 30 minutes of play.  Next for those of us who like detail but dislike horrible interfaces Panzer Corps has an easy to use interface that is nearly perfict.  Finally the depth of the historical missions are fun and exciting.  Eventually you will get attached to some of your brigades and be pitching a fit if one gets nailed in a bad spot.   Now for the bad....

One area that really could use some help is music, its ok but after awhile you wish you could just turn it off.  Its not cheep but its not well done.  Also while they were faithfull to the old PG game they really didnt try to bring in something new that would wow the audience.  Perhaps a research element, perhaps better naval options, perhaps better ways to manage air cover who knows but they really didnt change any core gameplay.  Yes this isnt necessarly a bad thing PG was a darn good game but that was 20 years ago.  

All in all the game is easily worth 50 without the DLC.  If you are a wargamer this is a must buy if there ever was one.  If you are on the fence or just havent played a war game before I would say there is no other game that could possibly be a better game to try.

9468040.review:
Panzer General updated.

Simply put, that's what Panzer Corps is. Gold Edition includes all previous DLC and is well worth the price. Have hundreds of hours with the game (including before it was released on Steam) and it is one of the best "simplistic" wargames out there. Variety of nationalities and units is superb, and each nation plays differently owing to variety of weapons and equipment.

My only complaint would be the scripting of campaigns. Regardless of what victory you may achieve (i.e: winning in Moscow 1941, or throwing back the allies on D-Day), it has no effect on the campaign overall. One battle leads into the next historical battle regardless of outcome. Playing the German campaign and win at D-Day? Next scenario is the Allied breakout from Normandy. Still, the game is well worth it IMHO.

9465360.review: The best is back, and even better than ever!

9464946.review:
A great remake of the classic Panzer General.  This has taken the great gameplay of the original and made it better by adding some new features (such as railway movement).  

The base game lets you play a campaign as the Axis where your core army survivors are taken from mission to mission through the historical battles of the war.   Its quite compelling to see your army gain experience over time, units gain medals and heroes occassionally appear.   Most missions involve capturing set objectives within time limits and if you are very successful then "historical what if" missions appear like the invasions of Britain and the USA.

There is a lot of hours of gameplay in the base game alone, so dont be put off by all the DLC.   I cant comment on the Grand Campaigns as I havent bought those.  I do own the Allied Corps expansion which is a meaty expansion of the game allowing you to play the WWII campaign as the British or US.  

You also might like it even if you dont normally play wargames as it is not complex and the battles are fast and fun.

9450112.review:
Als 1994 Panzer General erschien, bin ich Fan dieses Genres. Ich habe Panzer General über Jahre hinweg immer wieder gespielt, bis irgendwann die Meldung kam das es ein Remake gibt. Erwartungsvoll und ungedultig konnte ich es kaum erwarten, 2011 war es dann endlich soweit und ich muss sagen es steht dem Original in nichts nach. Ich verbrachte viele Stunden mit dem Spiel, überlegte mir Taktiken, kaufte Einheiten, überlegte welche Einheit welches Upgrade bekommt. Startete vielfach die Kampagne neu um einfach alles taktisch Perfekt zu meistern. Meine Kerntruppen wuchsen mir ans Herz und um so schmerzvoller war es, eine dieser Truppen zu verlieren. Hatte ich nicht gespeichert fing ich den Kampagnenabschnitt nochmal neu an. Ich hegte und pflegte meine Einheiten, denn nur so wuchsen sie zu schlagkräftigen Truppen heran. Es ist ein Spiel für Tüftler und Hardcoretaktiker die gern in hohen Schwierigkeitsgraden die Welt erobern wollen. Nur schade das es den Afrikafeldzug nicht integriert gibt, wie es bei Panzer General der Fall war. Ich hätte zu gern meine ans Herz gewachsenen Kerntruppen in die Wüste geschickt, um dort mal richtig auf zu räumen. Alles in allem aber, ein großes Lob an die Entwickler! Ihr habt eine Fangemeinde echt Glücklich gemacht auch wenn wir vielleicht nicht all zu viele sind. Blicken wir jedoch hoffnungsvoll in die Zukunft und freuen uns auf eventuell neu erscheinende DLC's. Wobei die verfügbaren DLC's für Wochen- oder gar Monatelangen Spielspaß sorgen. Auch ich werde das Remake wie einst das Original Panzer General über Jahre hinweg immer wieder spielen. Denn es gibt selten ein Spiel, dass einen so hohen Wiederspielwert besitzt wie dieses!!! Ich würde mich freuen wenn in der Zukunft ein Remake von Star General sowie Fantasy General erscheint. Ich denke ich spreche da für alle Fans des Hexfeldgenres...

Macht weiter so!!!

9449622.review: Finally, Slitherine have brought one of their games to Steam and it certainly is a good one. Panzer Corps is the spiritual successor to the Panzer General series, and it's turn based strategy at it's finest. I've had the game since roughly three years now, basically since it came out, and based on community feedback Slitherine made the game better than Panzer General was. If you like some turn based wargaming, this gem can't be overlooked and is a must buy.

9446684.review:
Panzer Corps. Wer früher gerne Panzer General, Allied General oder andere 5 Star Spiele gespielt hat, wird sich in PC sofort zurechtfinden. 
Hexfeldstrategie, rundenweise und abwechselnd. 
Einheiten werden die Kampange hindurch erfahrung gewinnen, aufgerüstet werden und Helden mit zusätzlichen Boni bekommen. Das Spielprinzip ähnelt im Grundsatz sehr stark dem ursprünglichen Panzer General, wenn auch mit kleinen gut durchdachten Verbesserungen im Design und den Regeln. Im Verlauf der Kampangene gibt es immer wieder Wendepunkte, bei denen das eigene Abschneiden in der jeweiligen Schlacht Einfuss auf den weiteren Kriegsverlauf nimmt, so ist z.b. so auch eine Invasion in England möglich. 

Es gibt die Möglichkeit Karten im 2 Spielermodus gegeneinander zu spielen, zum Teil sogar extra dafür ausgelegte, entsprechend angelegte Maps.

Zusätzlich gibt es die Möglichkeit DLC´s zu installieren. Zum einen Afrika Corps und Allied Corps, die eigentlich eigenständige Spiele sind, ursprünglich auch so verkauft wurden, eigene Kampangen über die Dauer des jeweiligen Scenarios enthalten und im Umfang PC ähneln.Bei diesen beiden Dlc´s ist dann auch der Kriegs bzw Kampangenverlauf an das Abschschneiden des Spielers in den jeweiligen Schlachten gekoppelt. 
Dann gibt es die Möglichkeit die Jahres Kampangen zu erwerben, die dann statt des gesammten Kriegs ein Jahr abbilden, allerdings mit nur eingeschränkten Einfussmöglichkeiten auf den Verlauf der Kampange. der Spieler hat dann allerdings die Möglichkeit seine Einheiten aus z.b. der ´39er Kampangen in die 40ér zu übernehmen, sammt erfahrungen helden etc. So dass man wenn man eine komplette reihe dieser DLC´s hat eine riesige Kampangene von 39 bis 45 durchspielen kann, mit xxx Maps, eine sehr schöne, wenn auch recht Zeitintensive Möglichkeit. Wobei hierbei allerdings der Verlauf des Kriegs immer gleich bleibt, selbst wenn man also z.b. die Schlacht(en) um Moskau gewinnt, wird in der Kampangen dann erklärt, das man sich aufgrund der Versorgungslage dann doch zurückziehen musste, so dass der Kriegsverlauf im grossen und ganzen gleich bleibt, also z.B. keine Landung in England.

Alles in allem. Panzer General war lange Zeit mein absolutes Lieblingsspiel, dies wurde nun von Panzer Corps vom Thron gestossen, das alles einen kleinen Tick besser macht.

Daumen Hoch für das meiner Ansicht nach beste Kampangenen Hexfeldspiel zum 2.WK aller Zeiten.

So, nach hunderten Stunden mit diesem Spiel ein weiters Fazit : mittlerweile sind diverse Erweiterungen erschienen, man kann nun auch auf russischer und Anglo/Amerikanischer Seite spielen, 100erte neuer Szenarien, die jeweiligen Besonderheiten der Alliierten wurden teilweise sehr gut eingefangen. Ich bin immer noch begeistert von Panzer Corps, auch der 2-Spieler Modus ist gut gelungen, Thumbs UP

PS: Ich habe keinen der Teile kostenlos erhalten und wurde nicht für den Test bezahlt oder sonstwie belohnt.

Auch x Jahre nach diesem Review spiele ich PC immer noch gerne und regelmässig.

9446520.review: 比较容易  上手的策略游戏 难度适中，是以前装甲元帅的改装版二战迷不容错过好多IF情节

9444081.review:
This a great turn-based strategic game. Certainly for players who remember Panzer General and any of it's successors. This is the ultimate version.

For player who don't know this legendary game: this game keeps it simple in graphics and sound but that is also what makes you focus on the tactical gameplay of the scenario's and the strategic building of your army core.
On the surface this game looks deceivingly simple but once you get to know all the game mechanics, you will soon understand how much planning and thought you can put in this game on the higher difficulty levels. The game mechanics are sadly not all super transparent at first, but using CTRL Click on a unit give you a detailed combat prediction and "L" give you the actual combat result from the last combat.

Don't be misdirected by the many DLC's, keep in mind that this game was released in late 2011. The Grand Campaign let's you replay historical scenario's. As the basic game give you more a revisit of the original Panzer General scenario's with extra's (heroes) and some improvements like interface and gameplay settings.

I haven't played Allied Corps or Afrika Corps but those two games bring a whole other twist to the game.

And I haven't even talked about all the cool Mods and custom scenario's that have been build for this game. Just check out the forums of Slitherine if you want to get to the bottem of this game.

For me, as a fan of the turn-based tactical and strategic games, this is the perfect WWII game. It focusses on the main issues at hand: how to succeed in combat. Logistics seem too simple at first glance but you will learn that if you don't keep your troops together you will soon be out of supplies and find that your units can't perform any more.

So this game get's 9/10 from me.

9443764.review: This game is great for any fan of Panzer General or WWII Strategy fan.  Lots of units, lots of upgrades, lots of DLCs.  Constant support from the folks at Slitherine and Matrix.  Play by mail or hotseat multiplayer, and even a vibrant forum community to help with questions or offer advice.  This is probably my most favored game (as is evident by the time Ive spent playing it) and constantly return to play another round.  Or 5.

9442136.review: Great to see the Panzer Corps series has finally come to steam.  It is one of the best turn based WW2 strategy games that I have ever played. It is easy to get into but has tactical depth.  Large variety of units to build your core army with throughout the game, there is nothing like having an early panzer crew survive long enough that they are a vetern Tiger crew by the games end.  Only downside is the Afrika Corps and Allied Corps are not stand alone because the original Panzer Corps is made obsolete by the Grand Campaign DLCs.  The Grand Campaign DLCs are by far the best value in each being a whole campaign in which your core units are saved and can be carried over to the next chapter of the war.  Allied Corps is great and allows you to play the western Allies starting in North Africa until victory in Western Europe.  Afrika Corps is great and featres some of the more challenging battles in the series while focusing on DAK and Italian forces in North Africa.  Great to finally see Slitherine/Matrix games apearing on steam for the historical strategy gaming crowd.

9442073.review:
On steam i have a different nick than on Slitherine.com, but i am much better known in the Panzer Corps community as Nikivdd.

I bought the game as soon as it was released 3 years ago and i went into Panzer Corps modding less than a month later.

Ladies and Gentlemen, the rebirth of Panzer General is called Panzer Corps. A dream becoming reality, as i have always been a PG fanatic and finally i no longer needed dosbox to play the best turn based strategy game every devised. The main game of Panzer Corps comes with a tutorial campaign (for new players) and a basic campaign, spanning WW2. Single scenarios can be played as well and not to forget, the possibility to play multiplayer games.

Africa Korps and Allied Corps are two great add-ons where in Africa Korps you can command and purchase a mixed force of Italian and German troops and where Alllied Corps offers the opportunity to start either as the Americans or the British. The British campaign of Allied Corps kicks off as a tutorial, in which difficulty augments slowly but it does feel good to kick the Italians big time in the butt, but when Rommel finaly arrives, you will need all your command abilities to outsmart the Desert Fox. For every campaign, you can make a lot of choices in terms of difficulty (very detailed), terms of game play and you can built and expand your army with a whole variety of units. You can even be rewarded an extra unit from time to time, SE units called, that do not count towards the number of units you can have in your army. Africa Korps and Allied Corps are guarantees for many hours of extra game play. It is not only while playing Civ 5 that a little voice says...one more turn please.... Hopefully your Africa Korps will march into Egypt :)

The Grand Campaign (the DLCs 39-40 and 41-45 East and 42-45 West) offer over a hundred new scenarios. Each year of the war is a campaign on its own, but oh so special, that when you finish for example DLC 39, you can carry over and import (by prompt) your army in DLC 40! You can also start any DLC of any given year, with the pre-placed army. You will experience Stalingrad as General Paulus or D-Day as FM Rommel.

Panzer Corps which is now finally available on Steam, is not the same game as it appeared three years ago. It became twice as good by several patches, new content, and surely by the tremendous feedback by the Panzer Corps community. How many games are out there, where the community has a say in the development of a game?
I gladly admit, I have never enjoyed a community as much as the Panzer Corps community and as such to be part of a great family and i made a lot of new friends in the process.

So, if you decide to buy the game on Steam, keep in mind that you reap the fruits of three years of game improvements!

And in the meantime the PC community awaits with great anticipation, the next installment, namely, Soviet Corps!

By Nikivdd (Panzer Corps beta tester and modder).

9441441.review: Easily in the top 5 best WW2 strategy turn-based games.  If you have an interest in History (WW2 specifically) and like turn-based games, then there is no reason not to buy this game.

9441192.review: This is a great game!!! and you don't need all the add-on. the main campaign that is in the game is log. mind me og panzer general 2 campaign. But the add-on makes the game longer....much much longer!!! Like turn based WWII, this iss the best you get.

9440585.review:
NB : Comments from playing with the original Slitherine version.

Taking into account all expansions, I played over 300 PzC scenarios. And it was a thoroughly enjoyable experience.
This is first and foremost a “game” rather than a “simulation”, yet the game has plenty of historical chrome and details. It is really easy to get into the game even if you are not familiar with WW2 tactics. However there is plenty of room to showcase your skills whether tactical or for managing your corps. For those reasons I'm glad to see this game coming to Steam and a wider audience.

Pros:
- Simple 2D game engine with neat gfx and convincing sound fx, that efficiently support gameplay. Multitask easily, no crash in 300 games! However I had a few problems on MP while uploading or replaying turns, it might be due to poor connection or security programms.
- Easy controls and clean UI, short loading times.
- The game was already good on release in 2011, but the developers made a number of improvements and refinements which make it even better today. Plus Steam achievements.
- The strongest game asset is probably the campaign game, where you develop your Corps scenario after scenario, your units gaining experience and heroes, you can also upgrade units with new equipments as the war progresses. Building you very own Corps, not only adds a layer of meta strategy over the individual scenarios, but it also awake the RPG fan in you.
- Plenty of scenarios with the DLCs.
- Over 800 unit types database, and easily modable, which is great for scenarios designers.

Cons:
- I wished the AI was better not necessarily in sheer strength but in adapting its behaviors to the various situations. It is not a problem when you discover the game, but with practice you'll note that the AI repeatedly uses the same pattern, and it is not so good at using combined arms.
- Basically scenarios outcome are: defeat, minor victory, major victory. I would have liked either finer grained, or better calibrated, victory conditions. As it is, it is too easy too achieve a major victory on most scenarios.
- Same for the difficulty levels. With 5 difficulty levels there should be something for everyone, however even the hardest level is relatively easy for experienced players. Nevertheless with the latest releases, there is now an “advanced settings” panel which allows to increase the difficulty to suit your skills.
- The scenarios of the original game are OK, but those of the DLCs are better, in particular the scale of the battles depicted works better with the game mechanisms.
- If you are looking for historical accuracy, you might get hurt.
- Most MP scenarios feels too much like a RTS rather than WW2 battles.
- Despite being very good on release, 4 years later the development is rather disapointing, the devs merely added more scenarios, they never cared to improve balance (especially in MP) or to add some gameplay elements (Actually most gameplay community requests were implemented in Order Of Battle: Pacific).

Overall I rate the game 85/100. I think it could easily appeals to strategy fans even if they are new to WW2 gaming, or to the grognards looking for a lighter yet very thematic recreation.
Recommended.

PS: note that the base Panzer Corps game at 19,99€ is a fully featured self contained game, the numerous DLCs only add more campaigns. It is not like , say Civ V, where DLCs add significant game play elements you wouldn't want to play the game without.

I think it would take over 100 hours to complete all campaigns and scenarios of the base game once. And you'll probably want to play them several time to try new strategy. Plus many free quality mods already available.

Cheap maybe not, but very good value for money.

NB: as good as the game was upon release, the development over the year wasn't so good. Campaigns balance, Suply, Overpowered and unhistorical player core forces, AI weakness were never adressed. Especially the late sceanrios are poor, significantly poorer than the vintage game and East Grand Camapign.

9440380.review:
Panzer Corps is a modern version of Panzer General, and I have to say that it's been improved in every way. Although it's new to Steam it was originally released back in 2011 and I've been playing it for over two years, so don't let my Steam game time fool you.

GAME MECHANICS

One of the best things about this game is that it uses what I think of as "chess-like" or "rock/paper/stone" mechanics. While there are many hundreds of different units in the game, they're all grouped into specific types (infantry/tank/recon etc.). There are 9 different types of land and air units, each of which has distinct characteristics (just as different chess pieces move differently). Using those characteristics to their best advantage is key to success in the game, especially in combination with other units.

For example, infantry are best for attacking a city, but the city may be defended by an artillery unit behind it which gets a free attack against the infantry. So you could send a tank around the city to take out the artillery, but it's protected by an anti-tank gun. So then you send a tactical bomber in to bomb the artillery, but guess what, it's protected by an anti-aircraft gun! A successful assault against a city therefore, can often be a "chess-like" puzzle to solve. It's not just the strength of the units that counts, but the type of unit. Combined arms warfare is a must.

GRAPHICS

Although it still uses the classic 2D interface, the unit models are now displayed with a semi-3D look rather than side-on as in the original. They're higher res and detailed enough to make the many different unit types easily recognisable. The map graphics are still pretty basic compared to modern games but are a lot more detailed and pleasing to the eye than the very plain original. There are now two levels of zoom as well as the strategic map.

SCALE

The game is operational in scale, rather than tactical (individual battles) or strategic (whole war), and the actual scale is variable depending on what's being represented. So a scenario may cover the invasion of the whole of Norway, or just the island of Malta. In spite of the big difference, it works well. Tanks and infantry have to be adjacent to attack, while artillery can typically fire 2 to 3 hexes. Planes have a large movement area and need to be refuelled so can't stay in the air indefinitely.

SCENARIOS

The 26 scenarios cover the main battles throughout the course of World War Two in Europe. They can be played standalone as either side or as a complete campaign from the German perspective, allowing your core force to gain experience and upgrade throughout the war.

The scenarios themselves cover mostly the same battles as in the original Panzer General but they've been redesigned, often at a different scale, so the maps are not identical.

UNITS

There are many more unit types available in this version, including some very rare units not often seen in WWII games, giving considerably more tactical diversity. The AI has also been improved. New terrain types have been added, for example railways, which allow quick transportation between cities once you control them, which adds an interesting extra dimension to the transportation possibilities.

COMBAT CHANGES

The combat mechanics are basically the same as the original, but have been tweaked to be more user-friendly. For example, whereas a unit had to both move and fire before selecting another unit, now movement and firing can be done at different times during the turn. For example, previously if you moved a unit then selected another unit before firing the first one, it would lose the ability to fire. Now it doesn't, so you can move unit 1, then move unit 2, then attack with unit 1. This gives you a lot more flexibility in how you organise your combined attacks.

Also, artillery can now be fired after moving. Perhaps not so realistic, but a lot easier to manage. Previously, when advancing, the artillery was always playing catch-up and often took a long time to get into position before you could actually use it. Now, you can move a melee unit forward, advance an artillery unit into the hex it just vacated, fire with the artillery, then attack with the melee unit once the defenders have been suppressed. Much more convenient! Additionally, many artillery units now have a longer range, 3 hexes instead of 2, making it even more useful.

CONCLUSIONS

As a long time wargamer (starting with Panzer Blitz in 1979), I'd have to say that this is possibly the best ALL-ROUND wargame I've ever played. It's a lot more polished and bug free than most other turn based wargames, it has enough depth and strategy to satisfy experienced wargamers, yet it's still accessible enough for newbies to the genre to enjoy, which is quite a brilliant balancing act.

It's definitely not a grognard's game, it doesn't contain complex spreadsheets and have hundreds of units to move every turn, but that's a good thing IMO. I've played overly complex strategy games in the past and quite frankly, the depth of detail can become tedious and take much of the fun out of the game. This game has relatively small numbers of units in each scenario and is quick to play. It has a very high fun factor that more serious games lack, whilst still containing plenty of strategic depth and a lot of detail and accuracy for the history buffs.

CIV V SIMILARITY

It's been admitted by Firaxis that the new combat system in Civilization V was partly based on Panzer General. Therefore all those Civ 5 fans who enjoy the new 1 unit per hex combat system would probably find this game very appealing, since there are a lot of similarities there. The big difference is that Firaxis over-simplified the combat system, whereas in Panzer Corps it's more detailed and realistic (and thus more enjoyable if you're purely in the mood for combat rather than developing an entire civilisation).

VERDICT

I highly recommended this game for all turn based strategy fans, especially those interested in historical recreations of actual battles in World War II.

39477206.review:
Si vous cherchez réflexes, effets visuels et adresse, passez votre chemin ! Mais si vous voulez (re)découvrir la seconde guerre mondiale au travers de nombreux champs de bataille et via le prisme passionnant des matériels militaires, ce jeu est pour vous. En effet, vous allez devoir mener, de bataille en bataille, vos propres régiments (qu'il faudra chérir et rééquiper en permanence) ainsi que quelques auxiliaires qui s'ajoutent parfois aux scenarii. Vos troupes gagneront en expérience. Vous devrez recruter (un peu) à chaque fois en prenant soin de constituer une armée équilibrée : chars, aviation, infanteries (et toutes leurs déclinaisons !) sans écarter la DCA, la reconnaissance, les anti-chars, etc...
Bref, des choix, des paris, de la réflexion et un systeme contre la montre qui vous pousse à rejouer les scenarii sans cesse, pour tenter de faire mieux que la dernière fois. 
Cette réécriture (sage) de la version originale est parfaite : elle n'a pas dénaturé le jeu et affiche un graphisme amélioré. 
Dernier détail : une partie se lance en 15" montre en main. Qui dit mieux ?
